body: Holly molly 20k connections batman. Was this a regression or did `NullPool` never work?
LGTM btw.
Looks like the second `configure_orm` call was added here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/b56cb5cc9

I was also checking the authentication using OPENID, even though i successfully sign in with Okta, the Airflow application says access denied with and present me the login screen and the Okta logo too doesnt appear

in webserver_config.py
OPENID_PROVIDERS = [
{ 'name': 'OKTA', 'url': 'https://dev-947022.oktapreview.com' }]

developer Okta configuration
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10759449/39852784-1147702e-53e4-11e8-8766-184d8c916991.png)

Final result after successful Okta login:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10759449/39852856-90523610-53e4-11e8-9e9b-24f39eca86c7.png)

Hey @Fokko , I know airflow has many files which has flake8 errors. I would do it one at a time and start fixing flake8 errors for couples of file. Let me know if it looks ok to you and I could continue to fix the rest.
Just FYI: I verify airflow webserver starts correctly after the flake8 change.

LGTM +1

@asfgit why not included this in 1.10 branch?
@ese this should be in the 1.10 branch. I’ll include it tomorrow.

@ThomasVdBerge 

Add `launchType='EC2'` to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/7ca45b252bbeeb2de223a835b8fa8b6b6200423c/tests/contrib/operators/test_ecs_operator.py#L120

i.e.

```
client_mock.run_task.assert_called_once_with(
            cluster='c',
            launchType='EC2',
            overrides={},
            startedBy=mock.ANY,  # Can by 'airflow' or 'Airflow'
            taskDefinition='t'
        )
```

Do the same here https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/7ca45b252bbeeb2de223a835b8fa8b6b6200423c/tests/contrib/operators/test_ecs_operator.py#L98

This should pass the failing tests.

I think this is superseded by the lineage PR. It should set/use inlets and outlets. Otherwise every operator is going to implement its own.

See: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3321

Oh, most definitely @bolkedebruin, this seems like a big change which makes this PR unnecessary. Do you think lineage might end up in 1.10?

I propose that we close this PR; there is some code here that is still relevant, concretely the tests for wildcard use, but this was piggybacked here anyway. So I will open another issue and PR and move the code there.
LGTM, great finding.
Also, can you provide full steps to reproduce? I commented as much on the referring Jira.

hey @Fokko @r39132 , I reproduce the reporter's issue by running airflow backfill example_http_operator -s 2018-02-01 -e 2018-02-02  -i over master branch. I am still not very clear on what is the proper way to fix and what is the history on why we copy configuration this way :)

Thanks, can someone with write-access merge this?

great find 👍
Nice work!

This is the correct behaviour. Since you haven't given the slash in your `destination_object`, it is not being added in the final destination.

It is important to keep in mind that in GCS, just like in S3, objects are not actually put into "directories" -- object names are simple strings which are for convenience treated as directories if their names include slashes. Therefore, constructing an object's name should not assume that the goal is to add a "directory"; a slash is just another character in the name.

To take your example, if your `destination_object` included a trailing slash -- `example_3_copy/` -- the original behaviour would produce e.g. `gs://bucket1/example_3_copy//usa_names_1910_current_000000000000.avro`; and in GCS two slashes do not get conflated to one as in a filesystem. Instead, your GCS console would show an extra level of "directory" with an empty string for the name.

Not presuming the use of "directories" also makes things more flexible -- it is easier to add a wanted slash in `destination_object` than to remove an unwanted one added by the operator.

Basically, using `destination_object` with the wildcard replaces the prefix (the part before the wildcard) with the `destination_object`; if the former ends with `/` so should the latter.

I agree with you on some aspects. But if you take an example of how `gsutil` works:

```bash
gsutil cp -r 'gs://bucket1/example_3/avro/*.avro' 'gs://bucket1/example_3_copy'
```

will copy all the avro files to `example_3_copy` directory.

But I agree: directory is just an object with trailing `/` for e.g `example_3_copy/` so can you please add some documentation regarding the same as well? i.e. "If you want to copy your source objects to a directory add a trailing `/` ". Also, please add an example usage in the documentation similiar to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/92363490b725cca345298a9f10613257a7500c9a/airflow/contrib/operators/gcs_list_operator.py#L52:L58 or something like the below example and explaining it.

```python
move_gcs = GoogleCloudStorageToGoogleCloudStorageOperator(
        task_id='move_gcs',
        source_bucket='bucket1',
        source_object='example_3/avro/*.avro',
        destination_bucket='bucket1',
        destination_object='example_3_copy/', # Add "/" if destination object needs to be a directory
        google_cloud_storage_conn_id='airflow-service-account'
    )
```
